text: I don’t follow her out. The moment the door closes, I regret it—but I push the bar in deeper anyway, like I’m wrestling my own impulse into place.
The fire in the hearth flickers. I stare at the light, forcing myself to believe: she doesn’t need me. She never has. She never needs anyone.
But the silence is torture. Every crack of burning wood sounds like fighting somewhere far away; every gust of wind feels like footsteps stopping outside the door.
I stand up, then sit down. Sit down, then stand again. In the end, I wipe the table three times and set the glasses back to the exact same angle.
I don’t know what I’m waiting for—until soft footsteps come from the stairs.
They’re steady. Familiar. Like someone who’s walked this path hundreds of times.
Alicia emerges from the shadow of the stairwell. Snow clings to the edge of her cloak. There’s a fresh cut across her knuckles.
She doesn’t look at me—as if meeting my eyes would create unnecessary emotion.
“You’re back.”
“Mm.”
She tosses something onto the counter. The soft clink of metal on wood makes my chest tighten.
It’s a ring-shaped token, its edge scorched and pitted—as if it’s been torn straight out of fire.
“Is that… from the Echo Circle?”
“Their mark.”
“I paid them a visit. Saves them from trying the old routine.”
She says it like it’s nothing—but her shoulders are visibly tense, the strain of someone who’s already pushed past her limit.
“A real nuisance.”
“You went alone again?”
She finally looks at me, just for a moment. There’s no reproach in her eyes—only a cool clarity that says: don’t complicate this.
“You did the right thing, staying here.”
“If you’d come, I’d have had to split my focus protecting you.”
She pauses, as if swallowing something even more blunt.
“I don’t want another variable.”
She nudges the token closer. Her fingers tremble slightly. She pulls her hand back at once, like she doesn’t want me to see.
“You’re hurt.”
“Just a scratch.”
“Don’t ask how.”
She pulls her cloak tighter around her shoulders, like she’s trying to hide the smell of blood along with everything else.
“I’ll handle the Echo Circle.”
“You just keep the tavern safe. Keep yourself safe.”
Only after saying that does her breathing seem to settle back into her chest. She pockets the token and turns toward the stairs.
“Are you going out again tomorrow?”
“Tomorrow’s the final round.”
“This isn’t over yet.”
At the foot of the stairs, she stops—like she’s finally allowing herself a single leak of exhaustion.
“You did well tonight.”
It isn’t praise. It’s confirmation: you’re alive, and you weren’t pulled in.
